canonical_explanation.text: Microorganisms are tiny living organisms that cannot be seen with the naked eye and require a microscope for observation. They include bacteria, fungi, protozoa, algae, and viruses. Microorganisms are found everywhere: in soil, water, air, and even inside the bodies of other organisms. Many microorganisms are useful to us — bacteria like Lactobacillus help in making curd, yeast is used in baking bread and brewing alcohol, and fungi like Penicillium produce the antibiotic penicillin. Vaccines prepared from weakened or killed microorganisms protect us from diseases. In agriculture, Rhizobium bacteria fix atmospheric nitrogen in the root nodules of leguminous plants. However, some microorganisms cause diseases in humans (e.g., tuberculosis, malaria), animals, and plants. Food spoilage is also caused by microorganisms, and preservation methods like drying, salting, pasteurisation, and refrigeration help prevent this.
rules: Microorganisms are classified into five major groups: bacteria, fungi, protozoa, algae, and viruses.
Viruses are considered to be on the borderline of living and non-living; they reproduce only inside a host cell.
Lactobacillus bacteria convert milk into curd.
Yeast is used in baking (CO2 makes dough rise) and in producing alcohol (fermentation).
Antibiotics (e.g., penicillin) are medicines produced from bacteria or fungi that kill or stop the growth of disease-causing microorganisms.
Vaccines contain weakened or killed pathogens that stimulate the body to produce antibodies.
Rhizobium bacteria in root nodules of legumes fix atmospheric nitrogen into the soil.
Communicable diseases spread from an infected person to a healthy person through air, water, food, or direct contact.
Food preservation methods include pasteurisation, drying, salting, adding sugar, refrigeration, and use of preservatives.
The nitrogen cycle involves nitrogen fixation, nitrification, and denitrification by various microorganisms.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a group of microorganisms?
questions.explanation_correct: Insects are not microorganisms. Microorganisms are classified into five major groups: bacteria, fungi, protozoa, algae, and viruses. Insects are multicellular organisms visible to the naked eye.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bacteria, fungi, and algae are all groups of microorganisms. Insects are multicellular animals that can be seen without a microscope and are not classified as microorganisms.

questions.question_text: Microorganisms can be seen with the help of a:
questions.explanation_correct: Microorganisms are too small to be seen with the naked eye and require a microscope for observation. Some like bacteria can only be seen under a compound microscope, while others like some algae can be seen under a simple microscope.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A telescope is used to view distant objects in space. A magnifying glass can only enlarge slightly and cannot reveal most microorganisms. A periscope is used to see over obstacles. A microscope is the correct instrument for viewing microorganisms.

questions.question_text: Which of the following organisms can reproduce only inside a host cell?
questions.explanation_correct: Viruses can reproduce only inside a host cell. Outside a host, they behave like non-living particles. This is why viruses are considered to be on the borderline of living and non-living things.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bacteria, fungi, and protozoa can all reproduce on their own without needing a host cell. Only viruses require a living host cell to multiply, as they lack the cellular machinery for independent reproduction.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a unicellular organism?
questions.explanation_correct: Amoeba is a unicellular protozoan organism. It consists of a single cell that performs all life functions. Mushrooms are multicellular fungi, ferns are multicellular plants, and earthworms are multicellular animals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mushrooms, ferns, and earthworms are all multicellular organisms. Amoeba is a single-celled protozoan that is a classic example of a unicellular microorganism.

questions.question_text: Algae are classified as microorganisms even though some can be seen without a microscope. This is because:

options.text: Many algae species are microscopic, though some form visible colonies or seaweeds
Algae are actually plants, not microorganisms

questions.explanation_correct: While some algae like seaweeds are visible, many species of algae are microscopic single-celled organisms. The group is classified as microorganisms because the majority of species are microscopic in nature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not all algae are microscopic, and some form large visible structures. However, the group is included in microorganisms because most species are microscopic. Algae are not true plants and they can perform photosynthesis.

questions.question_text: Which microorganism is used to convert milk into curd?
questions.explanation_correct: Lactobacillus is a bacterium that converts milk into curd. It multiplies in warm milk and converts the lactose (milk sugar) into lactic acid, which causes the milk to thicken and form curd.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Yeast is used in baking and brewing. Rhizobium fixes nitrogen in soil. Penicillium produces antibiotics. Lactobacillus is the specific bacterium responsible for converting milk into curd.

questions.question_text: Yeast is used in the baking industry because it:

options.text: Produces carbon dioxide that makes the dough rise

questions.explanation_correct: Yeast produces carbon dioxide gas during fermentation, which gets trapped in the dough and makes it rise. This is why bread and cake are soft and fluffy after baking.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Yeast does not add colour, kill bacteria in flour, or make bread salty. Its role in baking is to produce CO2 through fermentation, which causes the dough to expand and become soft and spongy.

questions.question_text: The first antibiotic discovered was:
questions.explanation_correct: Penicillin was the first antibiotic discovered by Alexander Fleming in 1929. He noticed that the Penicillium fungus produced a substance that killed bacteria growing on a culture plate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Streptomycin, tetracycline, and erythromycin were all discovered later. Penicillin, discovered by Alexander Fleming from the fungus Penicillium notatum, was the world's first antibiotic.

questions.question_text: A small amount of curd is added to warm milk to make fresh curd. This is because:

options.text: Curd contains salt that thickens milk
Curd contains Lactobacillus bacteria that multiply and convert the milk into curd
Curd adds water to the milk

questions.explanation_correct: A small amount of curd acts as a starter culture because it contains Lactobacillus bacteria. When added to warm milk, these bacteria multiply rapidly and produce lactic acid, which converts the entire batch of milk into curd.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Curd does not contain salt, cool the milk, or add water. It serves as a source of Lactobacillus bacteria, which need warm conditions to multiply and convert the lactose in milk into lactic acid, forming curd.

questions.question_text: Antibiotics should not be taken unless prescribed by a doctor because:

options.text: Unnecessary use can lead to antibiotic resistance and may kill beneficial bacteria
They are available only in hospitals

questions.explanation_correct: Unnecessary use of antibiotics can cause bacteria to develop resistance, making the antibiotics less effective when actually needed. Antibiotics can also kill beneficial bacteria in the body, disrupting normal body functions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cost, allergies, and availability are not the primary reasons. The main concern with unsupervised antibiotic use is the development of antibiotic-resistant bacteria and the destruction of beneficial gut flora.

questions.question_text: The process by which sugar is converted into alcohol by yeast is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Fermentation is the process by which yeast converts sugar into alcohol and carbon dioxide in the absence of oxygen. This process is used in making wine, beer, and bread.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pasteurisation is a heat treatment to kill microorganisms in milk. Nitrogen fixation converts atmospheric nitrogen to usable forms. Decomposition breaks down dead organic matter. Fermentation specifically refers to the conversion of sugar to alcohol by yeast.

questions.question_text: Which disease is caused by a virus?
questions.explanation_correct: Common cold is caused by a virus (rhinovirus). Tuberculosis is caused by bacteria, malaria by a protozoan (Plasmodium), and cholera by bacteria (Vibrio cholerae).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tuberculosis and cholera are bacterial diseases. Malaria is caused by a protozoan parasite. The common cold is the viral disease among these options, caused by rhinovirus.

questions.question_text: Malaria is caused by which type of microorganism?
questions.explanation_correct: Malaria is caused by a protozoan parasite called Plasmodium, which is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected female Anopheles mosquito.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Malaria is not caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi. It is caused by the protozoan Plasmodium, which enters the bloodstream through mosquito bites and infects red blood cells.

questions.question_text: Communicable diseases are spread through:

options.text: Air, water, food, or direct contact

questions.explanation_correct: Communicable diseases can spread through multiple modes: air (cough, sneeze), water (contaminated drinking water), food (contaminated food), and direct contact with an infected person or animal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Communicable diseases do not spread through only one mode. Different diseases have different transmission routes. For example, cold spreads through air, cholera through water, and ringworm through direct contact.

questions.question_text: A carrier of the malaria parasite is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The female Anopheles mosquito is the carrier (vector) of the malaria parasite Plasmodium. When it bites a healthy person after feeding on an infected person, it transfers the parasite.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Male mosquitoes feed on plant nectar, not blood, so they cannot be carriers. Female Aedes mosquitoes carry dengue virus, not malaria. Houseflies carry diseases like cholera and typhoid but not malaria. Only the female Anopheles mosquito transmits malaria.

questions.question_text: Which of the following diseases is caused by bacteria?
questions.explanation_correct: Typhoid is caused by the bacterium Salmonella typhi. It spreads through contaminated food and water. Polio, chickenpox, and influenza are all caused by viruses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Polio (poliovirus), chickenpox (varicella-zoster virus), and influenza (influenza virus) are all viral diseases. Typhoid is the bacterial disease among these options, caused by Salmonella typhi.

questions.question_text: Citrus canker in plants is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Citrus canker is a plant disease caused by bacteria. It affects citrus fruit trees like lemon and orange, causing lesions on leaves, stems, and fruit, and spreads through air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Citrus canker is not caused by viruses, fungi, or protozoa. It is a bacterial disease that affects citrus plants and is spread through wind-driven rain and contaminated tools.

questions.question_text: Which bacteria are responsible for nitrogen fixation in the soil?
questions.explanation_correct: Rhizobium bacteria live in the root nodules of leguminous plants and fix atmospheric nitrogen into a form that plants can use. This enriches the soil with nitrogen naturally.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lactobacillus converts milk to curd. Salmonella causes typhoid. Streptococcus causes throat infections. Rhizobium is the nitrogen-fixing bacterium found in legume root nodules.

questions.question_text: Pasteurisation is a process that involves:

options.text: Heating milk to about 70°C for 15-30 seconds and then cooling it quickly

questions.explanation_correct: Pasteurisation involves heating milk to about 70°C for 15-30 seconds and then rapidly cooling it. This process kills most harmful microorganisms without significantly changing the taste or nutritional value of the milk.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pasteurisation is not freezing, salting, or extended boiling. It is a specific heat treatment (named after Louis Pasteur) that briefly heats the liquid to a precise temperature to destroy pathogens while preserving quality.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a method of food preservation?

options.text: Keeping food in an open container
Storing food in a moist place
Leaving food at room temperature for days

questions.explanation_correct: Adding common salt is a traditional method of food preservation. Salt removes moisture from food and creates conditions in which microorganisms cannot grow, thus preserving the food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Keeping food in open containers, storing in moist places, and leaving at room temperature all promote microbial growth and spoilage. Salt preservation works by dehydrating food and creating an unfavourable environment for microorganisms.

questions.question_text: Jams and jellies are preserved for long periods because they contain a large amount of:
questions.explanation_correct: Jams and jellies contain a high concentration of sugar, which acts as a preservative. Sugar reduces the moisture available to microorganisms and creates conditions that prevent their growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adding water would promote spoilage. Salt is used for preserving pickles and meat, not jams. Vinegar is used for certain preserves but not typically jams. The high sugar content in jams and jellies is the key preservation factor.

questions.question_text: In the nitrogen cycle, the process by which atmospheric nitrogen is converted into usable compounds by bacteria is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Nitrogen fixation is the process by which certain bacteria convert atmospheric nitrogen (N2) into ammonia or nitrates that plants can absorb. Rhizobium in legume root nodules is a key nitrogen-fixing bacterium.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Denitrification is the conversion of nitrates back to atmospheric nitrogen. Nitrification converts ammonia to nitrites and nitrates. Ammonification converts organic nitrogen to ammonia. Nitrogen fixation specifically converts atmospheric N2 into usable forms.

questions.question_text: Edward Jenner discovered the vaccine for which disease?
questions.explanation_correct: Edward Jenner discovered the vaccine for smallpox in 1796. He observed that milkmaids who had contracted cowpox did not get smallpox, and used this observation to develop the first vaccine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The polio vaccine was developed by Jonas Salk. The cholera and rabies vaccines were developed by Louis Pasteur. Edward Jenner specifically developed the smallpox vaccine, which eventually led to the eradication of smallpox.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs of diseases are both caused by viruses?
questions.explanation_correct: Both polio (caused by poliovirus) and chickenpox (caused by varicella-zoster virus) are viral diseases. Typhoid and cholera are bacterial; malaria is protozoan (dengue is viral); tuberculosis and anthrax are bacterial.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Typhoid and cholera are both bacterial diseases. Malaria is caused by a protozoan, not a virus. Tuberculosis and anthrax are bacterial. Only option B has both diseases caused by viruses.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Viruses are considered to be on the borderline of living and non-living.
Reason: Viruses show characteristics of living things only when inside a host cell.
Choose the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct, and reason explains the assertion
Both are correct, but reason does not explain the assertion
Assertion is correct, but reason is incorrect
Both assertion and reason are incorrect

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are correct and the reason explains the assertion. Viruses behave as non-living crystalline particles outside a host, but inside a host cell they can reproduce and show living characteristics, placing them on the borderline.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The assertion is true — viruses are indeed on the borderline. The reason correctly explains why: viruses lack cellular machinery for independent reproduction and show life-like properties (such as reproduction) only when they hijack a host cell's machinery.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following statements about the nitrogen cycle is correct?
(i) Lightning can fix atmospheric nitrogen.
(ii) Rhizobium bacteria fix nitrogen in legume root nodules.
(iii) Denitrifying bacteria convert nitrates back to atmospheric nitrogen.
(iv) Plants directly absorb nitrogen gas from the atmosphere.
questions.explanation_correct: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Lightning fixes atmospheric nitrogen, Rhizobium fixes nitrogen biologically, and denitrifying bacteria return nitrogen to the atmosphere. Statement (iv) is incorrect — plants cannot directly absorb atmospheric nitrogen gas; they need it in the form of nitrates or ammonia.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statement (iv) is incorrect. Most plants cannot directly use atmospheric nitrogen (N2). They absorb nitrogen only in the form of dissolved nitrates or ammonium ions from the soil. Nitrogen must first be 'fixed' by bacteria or lightning.

questions.question_text:
Match the disease with its causative microorganism:
(a) Malaria — (i) Virus
(b) Tuberculosis — (ii) Protozoa
(c) Measles — (iii) Bacteria
Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct matches are: Malaria is caused by protozoa (Plasmodium) (ii), Tuberculosis is caused by bacteria (Mycobacterium tuberculosis) (iii), and Measles is caused by a virus (measles virus) (i).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Malaria is a protozoan disease, not bacterial or viral. Tuberculosis is caused by bacteria, not viruses or protozoa. Measles is a viral disease. The correct matching is (a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(i).

questions.question_text: A vaccine works by:

options.text: Directly killing all microorganisms in the body
Introducing weakened or dead pathogens so the body produces antibodies
Increasing body temperature to kill germs

questions.explanation_correct: A vaccine contains weakened or killed disease-causing microorganisms. When injected, the body's immune system recognises them as foreign and produces antibodies against them. If the actual pathogen enters later, the body can fight it quickly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Vaccines do not directly kill microorganisms, provide energy, or raise body temperature. They train the immune system by exposing it to harmless versions of the pathogen, triggering antibody production that provides future protection.

questions.question_text: Oil and vinegar are used to preserve pickles because they:

options.text: Prevent the growth of microorganisms by creating unfavourable conditions
Increase the water content of food

questions.explanation_correct: Oil prevents air (and hence aerobic microorganisms) from reaching the food, while vinegar creates an acidic environment that inhibits microbial growth. Together, they effectively preserve pickles for long periods.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While oil and vinegar do add flavour, their primary role in preservation is preventing microbial growth. Oil creates an anaerobic barrier, and vinegar's acidity makes conditions hostile for most microorganisms.

questions.question_text: Which microorganism is responsible for the formation of bread mould?
questions.explanation_correct: Bread mould (Rhizopus) is a type of fungus. Fungi thrive in warm, moist conditions and decompose organic matter like bread, producing the characteristic fuzzy growth seen on stale bread.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bread mould is caused by fungi (specifically Rhizopus), not by bacteria, viruses, or protozoa. Fungi are saprophytic organisms that feed on dead organic matter, making bread a suitable substrate for their growth.

questions.question_text: Viruses can reproduce on their own without a host cell.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Viruses cannot reproduce on their own. They need a living host cell to multiply because they lack the cellular machinery needed for reproduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Viruses are unique in that they can only reproduce inside a host cell. Outside a host, they are inactive particles and cannot replicate their genetic material or produce new virus particles.

questions.question_text: Antibiotics are effective against both bacterial and viral infections.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Antibiotics are effective only against bacterial infections. They do not work against viral infections like the common cold or flu because viruses have a completely different structure and mode of reproduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Antibiotics target specific structures in bacteria (like cell walls) that viruses do not have. This is why doctors do not prescribe antibiotics for viral infections such as the common cold.

questions.question_text: Cholera is a water-borne disease caused by bacteria.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Cholera is caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae and spreads through contaminated water and food. It is a classic example of a water-borne communicable disease.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Cholera is indeed a water-borne bacterial disease. The bacterium Vibrio cholerae contaminates water supplies, especially in areas with poor sanitation, causing severe diarrhoea and dehydration.

questions.question_text: Rhizobium bacteria can fix nitrogen when living freely in the soil without any plant association.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Rhizobium bacteria fix nitrogen only when they are in a symbiotic relationship with the root nodules of leguminous plants. They cannot fix nitrogen when living freely in the soil.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Rhizobium requires a symbiotic association with leguminous plants to fix nitrogen. The bacteria live inside root nodules where conditions are suitable for nitrogen fixation. Free-living nitrogen fixers include Azotobacter, not Rhizobium.

questions.question_text: Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin from the fungus Penicillium.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Alexander Fleming discovered penicillin in 1929 when he noticed that the mould Penicillium notatum produced a substance that killed bacteria on his culture plates.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Alexander Fleming accidentally discovered that the Penicillium fungus produced a bacteria-killing substance, which he named penicillin. This discovery revolutionised medicine.

questions.question_text: The female Aedes mosquito is the carrier of the dengue virus.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. The female Aedes mosquito (specifically Aedes aegypti) is the vector that transmits the dengue virus from an infected person to a healthy person through its bite.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Female Aedes mosquitoes transmit dengue virus when they bite humans to feed on blood. The female Anopheles mosquito, in contrast, transmits malaria.

questions.question_text: Microorganisms play an important role in cleaning up the environment by decomposing dead organic matter.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Decomposer microorganisms (bacteria and fungi) break down dead plants, animals, and organic waste into simpler substances. This recycling of nutrients is essential for maintaining ecosystem health.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Microorganisms act as decomposers, breaking down dead organic matter into simpler substances that enrich the soil. Without them, dead material would accumulate and nutrients would not be recycled.

questions.question_text: The five major groups of microorganisms are bacteria, fungi, protozoa, algae, and ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The five major groups of microorganisms are bacteria, fungi, protozoa, algae, and viruses. Viruses are unique as they show characteristics of both living and non-living things.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'viruses'. These five groups — bacteria, fungi, protozoa, algae, and viruses — are the major categories into which microorganisms are classified.

questions.question_text: The bacterium ___ is used to convert milk into curd.
questions.explanation_correct: Lactobacillus is the bacterium that converts milk into curd by producing lactic acid from the lactose (milk sugar) present in milk.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Lactobacillus'. This bacterium thrives in warm milk and converts the milk sugar (lactose) into lactic acid, which causes the milk proteins to coagulate and form curd.

questions.question_text: The process of conversion of sugar into alcohol by yeast is known as ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Fermentation is the process in which yeast converts sugar into alcohol and carbon dioxide. This process is used in making alcoholic beverages, bread, and other food products.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'fermentation'. During fermentation, yeast breaks down sugar (glucose) in the absence of oxygen to produce ethanol (alcohol) and carbon dioxide gas.

questions.question_text: The process of heating milk to about 70°C for 15-30 seconds and then cooling it quickly is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Pasteurisation is the process of heating milk to about 70°C for 15-30 seconds and then rapidly cooling it. This kills most harmful microorganisms while preserving the taste and nutritional value.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'pasteurisation'. Named after Louis Pasteur, this technique is widely used in the dairy industry to make milk safe for consumption by destroying disease-causing microorganisms.

questions.question_text: The bacterium ___ fixes atmospheric nitrogen in the root nodules of leguminous plants.
questions.explanation_correct: Rhizobium is the nitrogen-fixing bacterium that lives in symbiotic association with the root nodules of leguminous plants like peas, gram, and soybean.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Rhizobium'. This bacterium forms a mutually beneficial relationship with legumes — the plant provides food and shelter, while Rhizobium converts atmospheric nitrogen into a form the plant can use.

questions.question_text: Diseases that can spread from an infected person to a healthy person are called ___ diseases.
questions.explanation_correct: Communicable diseases are those that can spread from an infected person to a healthy person through air, water, food, or direct contact. Examples include cholera, common cold, and tuberculosis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'communicable'. These diseases are also called infectious or contagious diseases. They are caused by pathogens that can be transmitted from one person to another through various modes.

questions.question_text: The first antibiotic, ___, was discovered by Alexander Fleming from a fungus.
questions.explanation_correct: Penicillin was the first antibiotic, discovered by Alexander Fleming in 1929 from the fungus Penicillium notatum. It revolutionised the treatment of bacterial infections.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'penicillin'. Alexander Fleming discovered it accidentally when he noticed that mould (Penicillium) growing on a bacterial culture plate had killed the bacteria around it.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the smallest microorganism?
questions.explanation_correct: Viruses are the smallest of all microorganisms. They can only be seen under an electron microscope. Bacteria, fungi, and protozoa are all larger than viruses.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fungi and protozoa are relatively large microorganisms. Bacteria are small but still larger than viruses. Viruses are the smallest, typically ranging from 20 to 300 nanometres, and can only be seen with electron microscopes.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the correct way to prevent the spread of communicable diseases?

options.text: Maintaining personal hygiene and getting vaccinated

questions.explanation_correct: Maintaining personal hygiene (handwashing, clean surroundings) and getting vaccinated are the most effective ways to prevent communicable diseases. Vaccines provide immunity, while hygiene reduces exposure to pathogens.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Drinking contaminated water spreads disease. Avoiding all food is impractical and unhealthy. Crowded conditions increase disease spread. The correct approach combines vaccination with personal and community hygiene.

questions.question_text: Blue-green algae (cyanobacteria) are beneficial for agriculture because they:

options.text: Fix atmospheric nitrogen and enrich soil fertility

questions.explanation_correct: Blue-green algae (cyanobacteria) can fix atmospheric nitrogen and make it available to plants. They are commonly found in paddy fields and help enrich soil fertility naturally.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Blue-green algae do not kill pests, produce plant antibiotics, or prevent weeds. Their key agricultural benefit is biological nitrogen fixation, which adds nitrogen to the soil and reduces the need for chemical fertilisers.

questions.question_text: Which of the following preservation methods works by removing water from food?
questions.explanation_correct: Drying or dehydration preserves food by removing water. Since microorganisms need moisture to grow, removing water from food prevents their growth and spoilage. Sun-drying of fish, meat, and vegetables is a traditional example.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Refrigeration slows microbial growth by lowering temperature. Adding oil creates an airtight barrier. Vacuum sealing removes air. Drying specifically works by removing the moisture that microorganisms need to survive.

questions.question_text: Ringworm is a skin disease caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Despite its name, ringworm is not caused by a worm. It is a fungal skin infection that causes ring-shaped red patches on the skin. It spreads through direct contact with infected persons or contaminated objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ringworm is misleadingly named. It is caused by fungi (dermatophytes), not by any worm, bacteria, or virus. The ring-shaped rash it produces on the skin gave it its common name.

questions.question_text: In the nitrogen cycle, which process converts nitrates in the soil back to atmospheric nitrogen?
questions.explanation_correct: Denitrification is the process by which denitrifying bacteria convert nitrates in the soil back to atmospheric nitrogen gas (N2). This completes the nitrogen cycle by returning nitrogen to the atmosphere.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nitrogen fixation converts atmospheric nitrogen to ammonia/nitrates. Nitrification converts ammonia to nitrates. Ammonification converts organic nitrogen to ammonia. Denitrification is the reverse process that returns nitrogen to the atmosphere.
